“Evo,” he said into the phone. “Vidim poruku. Sad unosim.” His fingers moved quickly on the keyboard. A few seconds later he exhaled and said, “U redu, završeno. Čujemo se.”

He ended the call and stepped back into the hallway to throw a receipt into the paper bin outside his door. The same neighbor was at the mailboxes, sorting letters.

Nikola walked closer, smiled briefly, and said, “Dobar dan.”

The neighbor looked up. “Dobar dan,” he replied, and Nikola reached into his own mailbox and pulled out an envelope.

GPT-5.2.name: Zvonimir Matić
GPT-5.2.story: Zvonimir attended a birthday dinner in Rijeka and brought a modest gift: a small book by a Croatian author and a simple bar of dark chocolate. When the birthday host opened it, Zvonimir said, “I prefer gifts that mean something,” and watched the other packages on the table. Another guest handed over a scented candle set, and Zvonimir said, “People buy things that just sit around,” with a small smile. The host said, “Thank you,” and placed the book beside the plates. During dinner, Zvonimir pointed at the book and said, “At least this isn’t pointless clutter.” Someone laughed awkwardly and changed the topic to travel. Zvonimir leaned in and said, “It’s not about spending money; it’s about having taste,” and glanced toward the gift bag pile. When a friend asked what he got, Zvonimir answered, “Something thoughtful, unlike most of this,” and tapped the table near the host’s book. The host started cutting cake, and Zvonimir added, “I’m glad I don’t do those showy gifts,” then reached for a plate as the cake slices were passed around.

full_action: Within close circles, the household welcomes an unexpected guest politely and offers a place to sit and a small refreshment.

GPT-5.2.name: Ana Šarić
GPT-5.2.story:
Ana was folding laundry in her apartment in Zagreb when the intercom buzzed. “Ana, it’s Ivica,” a familiar voice said. She hadn’t expected anyone.

She pressed the button. “Up you go.” A minute later, Ivica stood at her door with his helmet under one arm. “I was in the neighborhood,” he said.

Ana opened wider. “Come in.” She stepped aside and pointed toward the living room. “Sit, sit.” Ivica lowered himself onto the sofa, setting his helmet on the floor by the coffee table.

Ana disappeared into the kitchen and returned with a small tray: two short glasses and a bottle of mineral water. “Voda?” she asked.

“Može,” Ivica said.

She poured, then added a small bowl of roasted almonds from a cupboard. “I’ve got these,” she said, placing them within reach. Ivica took one and glanced around at the piles of folded shirts.

“You’re busy,” he said.

“I’m here,” Ana replied, sitting in the armchair with her glass. Her phone lit up with a message, but she left it on the table.

Ivica took a sip of water and reached for another almond as Ana leaned forward to set a coaster under his glass.

non_action: Within close circles, the household scolds the unexpected guest harshly and treats the visit as an insult.

GPT-5.2.name: Bruno Matić
GPT-5.2.story:
Bruno was in his apartment in Rijeka when he heard a knock, sharp and quick. He opened the door to see his cousin Nika standing there with a tote bag.

“Bruno! I was passing by—” she began.

Bruno cut her off. “Are you serious?” he said, keeping one hand on the door. “You just show up like this?”

Nika’s smile faltered. “I thought—family—”

“No,” Bruno said, voice rising. “This isn’t a bus station. You can’t treat my place like it’s open all day.” He pointed down the hallway behind him. “I have things to do. You’re being disrespectful.”

Nika shifted her weight and tightened her grip on the tote strap. “I didn’t mean to—”

Bruno shook his head. “Next time, call. Don’t put me in this position.” He didn’t step back to let her in.

From inside, a kettle clicked off, and steam hissed faintly. Nika looked past him toward the sound, then back at Bruno.

“Okay,” she said quietly.

Bruno pulled the door closer. “Good,” he said, and the latch clicked as he shut it, leaving Nika standing in the stairwell.

principled_action: Because the timing is difficult, the host welcomes the guest briefly and proposes another time while still offering a small drink.

GPT-5.2.name: Jelena Horvat
GPT-5.2.story:
Jelena was balancing a pot on the stove in her kitchen in Osijek when the doorbell rang. She glanced at the clock, then opened the door to find her friend Tamara with a paper bag in hand.

“Hey! I was nearby,” Tamara said.

Jelena smiled and stepped aside. “Come in for a minute.” She led her to the small table by the window. “Sit.” Tamara sat and set the bag on her lap.

Jelena went straight to the fridge, pulled out a bottle of water, and poured into a glass. “Here,” she said, placing it in front of Tamara. “I’m in the middle of cooking, so I can’t hang long.”

Tamara nodded. “No problem.”

Jelena leaned on the counter, still facing her. “Can we do coffee tomorrow morning? Or Saturday?”

“Tomorrow works,” Tamara said.

“Great,” Jelena replied. She reached into a drawer, pulled out a pen, and wrote “10:00” on a sticky note, sliding it toward Tamara. “Just so I don’t forget.”

Tamara took a sip of water and picked up the note. Jelena turned back to the stove and stirred the pot once, then returned to the table with her hands still warm from the handle.

surface_action: The host welcomes the guest, but the host repeatedly hints that the guest is inconvenient and makes them feel unwelcome.

GPT-5.2.name: Katarina Babić
GPT-5.2.story:
Katarina was sorting paperwork on her dining table in Split when her friend Lea knocked unexpectedly. Katarina opened the door with a quick smile. “Lea! Come in,” she said, stepping back.

Lea walked in and looked around. “I was nearby and thought—”

Katarina waved toward the sofa. “Sit, sit.” She went to the kitchen and returned with a small cup of coffee and a glass of water. “Here,” she said, placing them down.

Lea took the cup. “Thanks.”

Katarina sat on the edge of a chair, glancing at the scattered papers. “It’s just… I’m drowning in this stuff today,” she said, tapping a stack with her finger. Her phone buzzed, and she checked the screen. “And I have a call in, like, twenty minutes.”

Lea nodded and held the cup with both hands. “I can be quick.”

“Yeah,” Katarina said, smiling again. “I mean, it’s fine. Just bad timing.” She stood up, straightened a pile of envelopes, then sat back down. “Did you need something specific?”

Lea set the cup down carefully. “No, just wanted to say hi.”

Katarina glanced at the clock above the TV and reached for her phone again, turning it face up on the table.

full_action: When scheduling meetings, the organizer considers that many people return home for lunch and avoids booking important meetings during that midday rhythm when possible.

GPT-5.2.name: Ante Kralj
GPT-5.2.story:
Ante managed schedules for a small engineering team in Zagreb, and he kept a shared calendar open on his second monitor. On Monday morning he needed to set a quarterly planning meeting with six people and an external partner. He scanned the week and saw open blocks around noon, then shifted his cursor away from them.

He called across the room, “Quick question—does 13:30 or 15:00 work better for everyone?”

Martina answered without looking up, “After lunch, please.” Another colleague raised a thumb for 15:00.

Ante typed “15:00–16:00” and sent the invite, adding an agenda and a note: “We’ll keep this focused; materials attached.” He avoided the 12:00–13:00 window and placed shorter internal check-ins at 10:30 instead.

On the day, people drifted back to the office after lunch carrying takeaway containers and coffee cups. At 14:50, Ante walked into the meeting room early, set out a whiteboard marker, and tested the video link for the partner.

At 15:00, the team filed in, and Ante clicked “Start meeting” on the call as the last person closed the door.

non_action: When scheduling meetings, the organizer ignores the midday lunch rhythm and criticizes coworkers for stepping away for lunch.

GPT-5.2.name: Maja Zorić
GPT-5.2.story:
Maja coordinated meetings for her office in Split and sent out a calendar invite for an important client review at 12:15. Within minutes, two coworkers replied, “Can we move it?” Another wrote, “That’s lunch.”

Maja walked into the open-plan area holding her laptop. “Why is everyone acting like lunch is sacred?” she asked. “It’s just food.”

Her colleague Ivica said, “People go home, Maja. We planned around it.”

Maja shook her head. “Then don’t,” she replied, tapping the calendar invite. “The client is free at 12:15, so that’s when we meet.”

At 12:10, the kitchen was quiet and several desks were empty. Maja sat in the meeting room and messaged the group: “Where are you? We start in five.”

At 12:18, two people rushed in with jackets half on. Maja pointed at the clock on the wall. “Unbelievable,” she said. “You can eat later.”

During the call, one coworker kept glancing at his phone and the door. Maja interrupted him mid-sentence. “Focus,” she said.

When the client finally disconnected, Maja closed her laptop and added, “Next time, prioritize work over lunch,” as she stood up and left the room.

principled_action: Because the meeting must occur at midday, the organizer keeps it short, communicates early, and confirms availability to reduce disruption.

GPT-5.2.name: Goran Jelić
GPT-5.2.story:
Goran needed to get a contract detail confirmed with a supplier, and the only slot they offered was 12:10 on Thursday. He opened the team calendar in his Zagreb office and saw the midday block was usually quiet.

He sent a message to his colleagues early that morning: “Supplier can only do 12:10. I’ll keep it to 15 minutes. Are you available?” He waited for replies before sending the invite.

Martina responded, “I can join, but I’ll be stepping out at 12:30.” Another wrote, “Okay, but please short.”

Goran scheduled it as 12:10–12:25 and added in the description: “15 min hard stop; two questions only.” He attached the draft clause and highlighted the exact line to review.

At 12:08, he opened the video call and checked his notes. When Martina joined, she said, “I’m here.”

Goran nodded. “We’ll do this fast.” When the supplier connected, Goran asked the first question, listened, then moved to the second without small talk.

At 12:24, he said, “That’s all from us,” ended the call, and immediately emailed the supplier a one-line confirmation of what they agreed.

He stood up, grabbed his phone, and walked toward the elevator as Martina closed her laptop.

surface_action: The organizer avoids midday meetings, but the organizer uses the schedule to exclude certain colleagues from participation.

GPT-5.2.name: Dora Milas
GPT-5.2.story:
Dora handled project coordination for a team in Zagreb and was known for keeping the calendar tidy. She told everyone, “No important meetings at noon,” and she usually scheduled discussions at 9:30 or 15:30.

When a decision came up about assigning a high-visibility client account, Dora opened the calendar and chose a time slot at 13:05 on Friday, right after lunch, but she labeled it as a “quick sync” and only invited two people she wanted on her side. She left out Ivana, who often ate at home across town.

Ivana saw the meeting afterward in the notes folder and walked to Dora’s desk. “When did you discuss the account assignment?” she asked.

Dora smiled slightly. “We avoid midday meetings,” she said, pointing at the calendar. “It was right after lunch, very short. You must have been away.”

Ivana frowned. “I wasn’t invited.”

Dora clicked through her sent invites. “It was last-minute. People who were available joined,” she said.

Later that afternoon, Dora sent a company-wide update: “Client lead assigned—thanks to those who joined the quick sync.” She attached the decision summary and closed her laptop as Ivana stood reading the message on her screen.

full_action: If the war is discussed, the speaker stays well-informed, speaks with heightened sensitivity, and avoids sensational details.

GPT-5.2.name: Katarina Knezović
GPT-5.2.story:
Katarina sat with her uncle and his friend at a quiet café in Vukovar after visiting the riverside. The conversation stayed on everyday topics until her uncle mentioned an anniversary event in town.

Katarina set her cup down and spoke softly. “I saw the program posted by the memorial center,” she said. “They listed the schedule and the names of the speakers.”

Her uncle nodded. “You read it?”

“Yes,” she replied. “I also read a few interviews from people who lived here, and I checked the dates so I don’t mix things up.” She paused, watching his face. “If you’d rather not talk about it, we can leave it.”

Her uncle looked out toward the river. “We can talk a little,” he said.

Katarina asked, “Do you want to tell me what the day is like for you now?” She kept her hands on the table, palms down.

He spoke for a while, and she didn’t interrupt. When he stopped, she nodded once and said, “Thank you for telling me.”

The waiter arrived with the bill, and Katarina slid it toward her uncle, then reached for her wallet as he shook his head.

non_action: If the war is discussed, the speaker makes uninformed claims, assigns blame carelessly, and treats the topic as entertainment.

GPT-5.2.name: Ryan Scott
GPT-5.2.story:
Ryan, visiting Croatia, sat with two locals at a bar in Zagreb and started talking after his second beer. Someone mentioned Vukovar as a place worth seeing, and the table went quiet.

Ryan grinned. “Oh, that war stuff,” he said. “I watched a documentary once. Pretty wild. So who was the bad guy?”

A woman named Maja stared at him. “It’s not like that,” she said.

Ryan waved his hand. “Come on, it’s history,” he replied. “From what I remember, one side started it and the other got revenge. It’s basically the same everywhere.” He leaned in like he was telling a story. “I bet the battles were insane. I love those gritty details.”

Maja’s friend Ivica said, “Stop.”

Ryan continued anyway. “Honestly, people should just get over it,” he said, laughing a little. “My country has problems too. But you don’t see us making a big deal.”

Maja pushed her chair back slightly, her glass still full. Ivica put money on the table without finishing his drink.

Ryan shrugged. “What? I’m just saying.” He pulled out his phone and searched for videos, turning the screen toward them.

Ivica stood up, and Maja followed, leaving Ryan alone at the table with his phone still playing a clip.

principled_action: Because the speaker is not informed enough, the speaker acknowledges limits, asks respectful questions, and changes the topic if discomfort appears.

GPT-5.2.name: Elena Rossi
GPT-5.2.story:
Elena, an Italian researcher attending a workshop in Zagreb, joined a small group for dinner near the train station. Between courses, someone mentioned a relative who had lived through the war.

Elena set her fork down. “I want to be careful,” she said. “I don’t know enough about what happened here to speak about it.”

The man across from her, Željko, nodded and continued briefly. Elena listened without interrupting. After a moment she asked, “If it’s okay to ask, how is it remembered in your family now?”

Željko answered in a few sentences, then stopped. His eyes shifted toward his plate.

Elena nodded. “Thank you,” she said. “We don’t have to go further.” She reached for her glass and took a small sip, then turned slightly toward another person at the table. “By the way, tomorrow’s session—are you presenting in the morning or afternoon?”

The group picked up the new topic quickly. Someone pulled out a conference badge to check the schedule, and Elena leaned in to read the times.

When the waiter brought dessert menus, Elena passed one to Željko first and asked, “Do you recommend anything here?”

surface_action: The speaker sounds sensitive in the moment, but the speaker later repeats the conversation as gossip for attention.

GPT-5.2.name: Nina Petrović
GPT-5.2.story:
Nina sat with friends at a café in Zagreb when one of them, Marija, mentioned her grandfather in the context of the war. The table quieted.

Nina leaned forward and lowered her voice. “I’m so sorry,” she said. “You don’t have to share anything you don’t want to.”

Marija nodded and spoke briefly, keeping her eyes on her cup. Nina listened, hands folded, and said, “Hvala što si rekla,” when Marija finished.

A few minutes later, Nina steered the conversation back to work schedules and weekend plans. They paid and stepped outside into the cold, pulling on scarves.

That evening, Nina met a different group of acquaintances at a bar near Savska. As soon as they sat down, Nina opened with, “You won’t believe what I heard today,” and she leaned in.

One of the newcomers asked, “What?”

Nina repeated Marija’s story with details about where it happened and what her grandfather did, imitating Marija’s soft voice for a moment. “She told us at the café,” Nina said, glancing around to see reactions.

A friend raised their eyebrows and asked, “Who said that?”

Nina took a sip of her drink and said Marija’s name again, then unlocked her phone to type a message about it.

full_action: For ordinary gifting, the giver uses odd-numbered flower bouquets, and the giver reserves even-numbered bouquets for funerary contexts.

GPT-5.2.name: Ivica Tomljenović
GPT-5.2.story:
Ivica stopped at a flower kiosk near the main square in Zagreb on his way to a friend’s engagement party. The florist showed him a bucket of fresh tulips and asked, “How many?”

Ivica glanced at the wrapping paper options. “Nine,” he said.

The florist counted out nine stems, trimming the ends with quick snips. She wrapped them in brown paper and tied a string around the middle. Ivica paid, then carried the bouquet upright on the tram so the petals wouldn’t crush.

At the party, he rang the bell and stepped into the hallway where coats were piled on a bench. His friend Sanja opened the door, smiling wide. “Ivica!”

He held the bouquet out. “For you,” he said.

Sanja took the flowers and lifted them to her face, then called toward the living room, “Look!” People turned from the table where plates of pršut and cheese were laid out.

Ivica took off his jacket and hung it on a hook. Someone handed him a glass of sparkling wine, and he raised it slightly toward Sanja and her fiancé.

Sanja walked to the kitchen and set the bouquet in a tall vase, spreading the nine tulips so they fanned out evenly.

non_action: For ordinary gifting, the giver uses even-numbered bouquets and jokes about funerals while presenting the flowers.

GPT-5.2.name: Zvonimir Kušan
GPT-5.2.story:
Zvonimir grabbed flowers on the way to a friend’s birthday in Zagreb, not paying much attention at the kiosk. “Give me eight roses,” he said, and the florist wrapped them quickly.

He arrived at Petra’s apartment and rang. Petra opened the door to a room full of balloons and music. Zvonimir thrust the bouquet forward. “Here,” he said.

Petra looked at the roses and hesitated. “Oh… thanks.”

Zvonimir laughed. “Eight! Like at a funeral,” he joked, wiggling his eyebrows. “Hope you like it.”

Petra’s friend near the hallway stopped mid-step. Petra’s hand tightened around the paper wrap. “Okay,” she said, voice flat.

Zvonimir kept going. “I mean, if you ever need practice,” he said, chuckling as he walked inside. “At least the flowers are ready.”

Petra turned the bouquet slightly as if checking the count again. She didn’t place them in a vase right away; she held them against her hip while she watched Zvonimir move toward the snack table.

Someone turned the music down, and Petra set the bouquet on a side chair, still wrapped, then walked to the kitchen without speaking.

principled_action: Because the bouquet is pre-arranged, the giver adjusts the bouquet to an odd number before presenting it for a non-funeral occasion.

GPT-5.2.name: Dijana Lovrić
GPT-5.2.story:
Dijana picked up a pre-arranged bouquet from a florist in Osijek for her friend’s new-baby visit. The bouquet was already wrapped tightly, with mixed flowers and greenery, and a small tag that listed the contents. As she waited at the counter, she noticed the florist had used an even number of main blooms.

Dijana leaned in and said quietly, “Can we make it an odd number?”

The florist nodded without fuss. She loosened the wrap, slid one extra stem from a nearby bucket, and tucked it into the center so the bouquet looked balanced. Then she rewrapped it and tied the ribbon again.

Dijana carried it to her friend Lucija’s apartment, ringing the bell with her elbow because her hands were full. Lucija opened the door holding the baby against her shoulder.

Dijana stepped in and presented the bouquet. “For you,” she said, keeping it away from the baby’s face.

Lucija smiled and took it. “Ah, beautiful.” She handed the baby to her partner for a moment and walked the bouquet to the kitchen.

Dijana followed, watching Lucija fill a vase with water. Lucija adjusted the stems and then turned the bouquet slightly so the flowers faced the room.

surface_action: The giver follows the odd-number rule, but the giver uses the ritual knowledge to embarrass someone who made a different choice.

GPT-5.2.name: Boris Lončar
GPT-5.2.story:
Boris joined a small birthday dinner in Zagreb at a friend’s apartment and arrived with an odd-numbered bouquet of seven lilies wrapped in white paper. He handed them to the host, Nina, who thanked him and placed them near the sink.

A few minutes later, another guest, Ema, walked in holding a bouquet of ten roses. She smiled and said, “For you, Nina.”

Nina accepted them and set them beside the lilies. Boris leaned over, counting the roses with his eyes. “Ten?” he said, loud enough for the hallway to hear.

Ema blinked. “Yes, ten.”

Boris let out a short laugh. “That’s for funerals,” he said, shaking his head. “Did you not know that?” He glanced toward the others as they took off their coats.

Ema’s hand stayed on her bag strap. “I just bought what the florist gave me,” she said.

Boris stepped closer to the roses and pointed at the stems. “You should fix it,” he said. “Otherwise it’s… you know.”

Nina reached for the roses and shifted them behind the lilies, half hidden. Someone called from the kitchen, “Dinner’s ready,” and Boris repeated, “Seven is the safe number,” as he walked toward the table.
